questions.text: One day after undergoing total knee replacement for advanced degenerative osteoarthritis, a 66-year-old man has progressive lower abdominal pain. The surgery was performed under general anesthesia and the patient was temporarily catheterized for perioperative fluid balance. Several hours after the surgery, the patient began to have decreasing voiding volumes, nausea, and progressive, dull lower abdominal pain. Medical history is remarkable for Sjögren syndrome. He does not smoke and drinks one to two beers on the weekends. Current medications include pilocarpine eye drops. He appears uncomfortable and is diaphoretic. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 130/82 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows a pelvic mass extending to the umbilicus. It is dull on percussion and diffusely tender to palpation. His hemoglobin concentration is 13.9 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9000/mm3, and platelet count is 230,000/mm3. An attempt to recatheterize the patient transurethrally is unsuccessful. Which of the following is the most likely underlying condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Several risk factors can contribute to postoperative AUR, including male sex, age > 50 years, joint arthroplasty, and preexisting urinary tract obstruction such as benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), which is the most common cause of bladder outflow obstruction and AUR in older men. An acute inability to micturate can be the initial presentation of BPH.

Since transurethral catheterization was not successful, a suprapubic catheter should be placed for immediate relief of the distended bladder. Following this, the patient should undergo a trial of voiding without a catheter. Furthermore, the outflow obstruction should be evaluated with a uroflowmetry test to quantify the obstruction, and the suitability for treatment options, e.g., with alpha-1 blockers, should be discussed.

B) INCORRECT:

A number of drugs that act on the autonomic system can cause AUR by either decreasing detrusor activity (parasympatholytic agents) or increasing urethral sphincter tone (sympathomimetic agents). Pilocarpine is, however, a direct parasympathomimetic agent that would increase detrusor activity, which facilitates bladder emptying. This patient also takes pilocarpine intraocularly, which makes it highly unlikely that the systemic concentration of the drug would be high enough to have any effect on the bladder.

C) INCORRECT:

Acute prostatitis is usually caused by a bacterial infection of the urinary tract and may also manifest with AUR. While this patient's history of indwelling catheterization puts him at higher risk for urinary tract infections, acute bacterial prostatitis usually manifests with spiking fevers, chills, and perineal pain. The absence of fever and a normal leukocyte count make acute prostatitis unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Urethral stricture is a possible cause of AUR. Iatrogenic manipulation (e.g., injury related to transurethral insertion of an oversized endoscope or catheter placement) is the most common etiology of urethral stricture. While this patient was catheterized transurethrally during surgery, it takes much longer than several hours for scar tissue of a urethral stricture to form. Recurrent urethritis may also cause urethral stricture. Because this patient has no history of previous surgeries requiring catheterization or recurrent urethral infections, urethral stricture is an unlikely diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Neurogenic lower urinary tract dysfunction (NLUTD) may manifest with AUR and is a common cause of bladder outflow obstruction, especially in young men and women. It results from injury to the central nervous system (e.g., multiple sclerosis, spinal cord injury, stroke) or the peripheral nerves that supply the bladder (e.g., diabetic neuropathy). Postoperative NLUTD, however, is usually only seen following spinal anesthesia and abdominopelvic surgeries, either of which can cause neural damage resulting in impaired autonomic bladder control; NLUTD is highly unlikely to occur as a sequela of total knee replacement. In addition, an outflow obstruction due to NLUTD would be correctable with recatheterization, which was unsuccessful in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient has postoperative oliguria, lower abdominal pain, and a palpable pelvic mass that is dull on percussion, suggesting bladder distention. In combination, these findings indicate acute urinary retention (AUR).

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl with recurrent urinary tract infections is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination. Renal ultrasound shows bilateral dilation of the renal pelvis. A voiding cystourethrography shows retrograde flow of contrast into the ureters during micturition. Histologic examination of a kidney biopsy specimen is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Diffuse interstitial infiltration with T lymphocytes

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diffuse interstitial infiltration with T lymphocytes can be seen in tubulointerstitial nephritis, which is most commonly caused by a hypersensitivity reaction to drugs (e.g., NSAIDs). It typically presents with fever, hematuria, flank pain, and eosinophiluria (acute tubulointerstitial nephritis), or low-grade proteinuria and progressive CKD (chronic tubulointerstitial nephritis).

B) INCORRECT:

Glomerular crescents, macrophages, and monocytes are common kidney biopsy findings in rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN), which presents as nephritic syndrome and acute renal failure.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of kidney biopsy tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

A hypercellular, crescent-shaped zone with an inflammatory infiltrate (yellow overlay) is visible within the glomerulus.

Glomerular crescent formation is a characteristic histological finding in RPGN.

C) INCORRECT:

Matrix expansion with mesangial proliferation secondary to IgA-based immune complex deposition is a characteristic finding in patients with IgA nephropathy, which typically presents as episodes of hematuria associated with upper respiratory tract or gastrointestinal tract infections.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of kidney tissue (PAS stain)

A glomerulus surrounded by numerous tubules is visible in the center of each image. There is a proliferation of mesangial cells (examples marked by yellow circles) with extracellular matrix deposition within the glomeruli. In IgA nephropathy, these changes can range from focal segmental (examples indicated by black arrows) to diffuse (examples indicated by yellow arrow-heads).

This is the characteristic histopathologic appearance of IgA nephropathy.

Blue outlines: Glomerular capillaries

D) CORRECT:

Cortical thinning with tubular atrophy is seen in patients with hydronephrosis. Chronic retrograde urine flow increases pressure within the nephron lumen and subsequently compresses adjacent blood vessels. Decreased blood flow through these vessels results in decreased renal perfusion and eventually ischemic tubular atrophy, and thinning of the renal cortex and medulla. Serum analysis in this patient will most likely show elevated serum creatinine levels, as both kidneys are affected.
Image Description:

On the left, there is a normal kidney with no obstruction to urinary outflow. Grade I hydronephrosis involves a dilation of the renal pelvis. In grade II, renal calyces are also dilated. Grade III leads to a flattening of papillae. In grade IV, the kidney is completely atrophied.

E) INCORRECT:

Prominent glomerular capillary loops due to thickening of the glomerular basement membrane are seen in membranous nephropathy, which typically occurs among adults and presents as nephrotic syndrome.
questions.hint: This patient presents with bilateral hydronephrosis and recurrent urinary tract infections secondary to vesicoureteral reflux.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was a restrained passenger. He reports pelvic pain and involuntary loss of urine, with constant dribbling. Examination shows perineal bruising and there is pain with manual compression of the pelvis. Pelvic ultrasound shows a normal bladder. Injury to which of the following structures is most likely responsible for this patient's urinary incontinence?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Pelvic splanchnic nerves originate from the sacral nerve roots S2–S4 and provide parasympathetic innervation to the rectum, erectile tissue, and detrusor muscle of the bladder. Injury to these nerves (e.g., due to pelvic trauma, as seen in this patient) causes decreased activity of the detrusor muscle, which results in impaired bladder contractility (atonic bladder), overdistention, and decreased sensation of bladder fullness. The resulting overflow incontinence typically manifests with involuntary loss of urine in the form of constant dribbling.

B) INCORRECT:

Genitofemoral nerve injury can occur as a complication of laparoscopic surgery (e.g., hernia repair) or compression (e.g., psoas abscess). Injury to this nerve would cause sensory loss in the scrotal skin and the upper and anterior medial thigh, as well as a decreased cremasteric reflex. Urinary incontinence would not be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

The superior gluteal nerve innervates the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, which are responsible for abduction of the hip. Injury to this nerve would result in a positive Trendelenburg sign but would not cause urinary incontinence.
Image Description:

The Trendelenburg sign indicates insufficiency of the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscles. It is tested for as follows:
(1) The pelvic level is assessed by comparing the height of both iliac crests.
(2) The patient is asked to stand on one leg, with the examiner continuously observing the level of the pelvis and the patient's posture. Normally, the pelvis is stabilized by the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscles, which prevent a pelvic drop to the opposite side.
(3) In the case of muscle insufficiency, the pelvis drops towards the unimpaired, unsupported side (free leg), which is known as the Trendelenburg sign.
(4) Tilting of the torso toward the contralateral side compensates for the pelvic drop on the unimpaired side, which is known as Duchenne sign. Because the Duchenne sign may mask the Trendelenburg sign, it is important to always inspect the patient's overall posture.

D) INCORRECT:

Ilioinguinal nerve injury most commonly occurs as a complication of laparoscopic surgery (e.g., hernia repair). Injury to this nerve would cause sensory loss of the upper medial thigh, the root of the penis, and the anterior one-third of the scrotum, as well as a decreased cremasteric reflex. Urinary incontinence would not be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Obturator nerve injury can also occur with pelvic trauma. Injury to this nerve would cause paralysis of the hip adductors and sensory loss in the medial thigh. Urinary incontinence would not be expected.

F) INCORRECT:

Femoral nerve injury can also occur as a result of pelvic trauma. Injury to this nerve would cause sensory loss in the anteromedial thigh and medial lower leg, as well as motor deficits of the quadriceps, iliacus, pectineus, and sartorius muscles (resulting in impairment in hip flexion, knee extension, and the patellar tendon reflex). Femoral nerve injury does not cause urinary incontinence.
questions.hint: This patient's urinary dribbling is consistent with neurogenic bladder secondary to pelvic trauma. The injured nerve is part of the autonomic nervous system.

questions.text: One month after undergoing surgical spinal fusion because of a traumatic spinal cord injury, a 68-year-old man comes to the physician because of lower abdominal pain. He last voided yesterday. Physical examination shows a suprapubic mass and decreased sensation below the umbilicus. Urodynamic studies show simultaneous contractions of the detrusor muscle and the internal urethral sphincter. Urinary catheterization drains 900 mL of urine from the bladder. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient’s urinary symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neostigmine can be used to treat the detrusor muscle hypomotility seen in flaccid neurogenic bladder or postoperative urinary retention. In these cases, the addition of an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor will allow more endogenous acetylcholine to stimulate the M3 receptors in the bladder and cause detrusor contraction. Neostigmine would exacerbate this patient's spastic detrusor muscle activity.

B) INCORRECT:

Finasteride is used to treat bladder outlet obstruction due to benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), as it decreases the size of the prostate. This man is at risk of having BPH, which is common in men > 50 years of age and can cause urinary retention. However, BPH typically has a gradual onset and rarely manifests with acute urinary retention as severe as seen in this patient. Finasteride has no effects on detrusor muscle activity or urinary sphincter contraction and would not be effective for the spastic neurogenic bladder seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Phenylephrine is a sympathomimetic alpha-1 agonist, which would increase the smooth muscle tone at the neck of the bladder and the internal urethral sphincter, thereby inducing urinary retention. Phenylephrine would be contraindicated in this patient with an already overactive sphincter muscle and spastic neurogenic bladder.

D) INCORRECT:

Bethanechol can be used to treat bladder hypomotility seen in flaccid neurogenic bladder or postoperative urinary retention. In these cases, the detrusor muscle is not contracting properly, and the addition of a muscarinic agonist will stimulate M3 receptors in the bladder, causing detrusor contraction and improved urinary outflow. This patient's urinary retention is due to a spastic neurogenic bladder, which would be exacerbated with muscarinic agonists; a muscarinic antagonist could be used instead.

E) CORRECT:

Alpha blockers such as prazosin are the most appropriate pharmacotherapy in patients with spastic neurogenic bladder because of their effects on smooth muscle relaxation of the neck of the bladder and the internal urethral sphincter, which can improve urine outflow. This patient likely had a spinal cord lesion near the level of T10 (decreased sensation below the umbilicus), which is now causing sympathetic stimulation of the urethral sphincter, as evidenced by the urodynamic studies. Alpha blockers are also a first-line therapy in urinary retention due to outflow tract obstruction caused by benign prostatic hyperplasia. The most common side effects of alpha blockers are postural hypotension and headaches.

A lower, sacral lesion would affect the parasympathetic bladder input and lead to a flaccid neurogenic bladder that is unable to contract.
questions.hint: This patient has signs and symptoms of spastic neurogenic bladder (detrusor sphincter dyssynergia) with urinary retention following spinal cord injury. Appropriate pharmacotherapy would involve inhibition of the detrusor and sphincter muscle.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of dull lower abdominal pain for 3 hours. He has not urinated for 24 hours and has not passed stool for over 3 days. He was diagnosed with herpes zoster 4 weeks ago and continues to have pain even after his rash resolved. He has hypertension, benign prostatic hyperplasia, and coronary artery disease. Physical examination shows a tender, palpable suprapubic mass. Bowel sounds are hypoactive. Abdominal ultrasound shows a large anechoic mass in the pelvis. Which of the following drugs most likely accounts for this patient's current symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Simvastatin is an HMG-CoA reductase inhibitor indicated for the treatment of coronary heart disease, which this patient has. While simvastatin can cause constipation, it does not possess anticholinergic effects and therefore would not explain this patient's acute urinary retention or hypoactive bowel sounds.

B) INCORRECT:

Pregabalin is an anticonvulsant that can be used in the treatment of polyneuropathies such as postherpetic neuralgia. It is a structural analog of the GABA neurotransmitter and binds to presynaptic neurons, reducing calcium currents and decreasing neurotransmitter release. While pregabalin can cause constipation, it does not possess anticholinergic effects and therefore would not explain this patient's acute urinary retention or hypoactive bowel sounds.

C) INCORRECT:

Dutasteride is a 5-alpha-reductase inhibitor that can be used in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia. It decreases intraprostatic DHT levels, reducing prostate size and thereby relieving prostatic obstruction of the urethra. Dutasteride does not possess anticholinergic effects and therefore would not explain this patient's acute symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Tamsulosin is a selective alpha-1 adrenergic receptor antagonist used in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia. Tamsulosin acts on alpha-1 receptors, relaxing the smooth muscle of the internal urethral sphincter to facilitate bladder voiding. Tamsulosin does not possess anticholinergic effects and therefore would not explain this patient's acute symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Amlodipine is a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker used in the treatment of hypertension. However, it does not possess anticholinergic effects and therefore would not explain this patient's acute symptoms.

F) INCORRECT:

Valproate is a classic anticonvulsant that offers only limited benefits for the treatment of postherpetic neuralgia. While valproate can cause constipation, it does not possess anticholinergic effects and therefore would not explain this patient's acute urinary retention or hypoactive bowel sounds.

G) CORRECT:

Amitriptyline is one of the most common tricyclic antidepressants (TCA) used for the treatment of postherpetic neuralgia. This class of drugs (especially tertiary amines such as amitriptyline) has strong anticholinergic effects that can result in AUR (due to a decrease in detrusor muscle tone and increase in internal urethral sphincter tone) and constipation (due to a decrease in intestinal peristalsis), as seen in this patient. Because of their anticholinergic effects, TCAs should be used cautiously in older individuals and in patients with conditions that predispose them to AUR, such as benign prostatic hyperplasia (see “Overview of antidepressants” table).
questions.hint: Severe lower abdominal pain, anuria, and a palpable anechoic lower abdominal mass suggest acute urinary retention (AUR). Given this patient's concurrent constipation and hypoactive bowel sounds, he is most likely taking a drug with strong anticholinergic side effects.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with lower abdominal pain for the past 2 hours. He describes the pain as an 8/10 in intensity with no radiation. He denies fever or chills. He has not passed urine since the early morning. He took oral diphenhydramine last night because he had difficulty falling asleep. He has a history of hypertension. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily but quit 1 year ago. Current medications include amlodipine. He appears restless. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 134/90 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows a tender palpable suprapubic mass. Digital rectal examination shows a mildly enlarged, nontender prostate without any palpable masses. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A bedside ultrasound scan shows a large anechoic mass in the lower abdomen. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?

choices.text: Obtain CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although finasteride reduces the incidence of AUR in patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia, which this patient most likely has, it is not used to treat acute episodes of urinary retention because it usually takes several months before it has a noticeable effect.

B) INCORRECT:

A suprapubic catheter can be placed in patients with AUR. However, a suprapubic catheter should only be placed if first-line therapy fails or is contraindicated.

C) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis is useful for diagnosing urolithiasis, which can cause AUR if a calculus obstructs the urethral orifice. However, in a patient with urolithiasis, the pain is usually colicky and, since most calculi contain calcium, a hyperechoic calculus with an acoustic shadow is typically seen on ultrasound. In a patient with AUR, a different step is more appropriate at this point.

D) INCORRECT:

Bethanechol can be used to treat acute postoperative urinary retention, postpartum urinary retention, or urinary retention in patients with a neurogenic bladder. Furthermore, even in the presence of such indications, bethanechol is not the first-line treatment, as it does not provide immediate relief.

E) CORRECT:

Relief of the overfilled bladder via transurethral catheterization is the treatment of choice for patients with AUR. Drug-induced AUR can result from decreased detrusor muscle contractility or increased urethral sphincter tone. Decreased detrusor muscle contractility is usually due to the anticholinergic effects of drugs such as anticholinergics, first-generation antihistamines, and tricyclic antidepressants. Increased urethral sphincter tone is typically due to the sympathomimetic effects of drugs such as beta and alpha-adrenergic agonists. Precipitating drugs, (e.g., drugs with sympathomimetic or anticholinergic effects) should be discontinued or substituted.

F) INCORRECT:

A normal saline bolus can be administered in patients with anuria secondary to prerenal acute kidney injury (AKI) as an attempt for fluid repletion. However, this patient's distended bladder indicates urinary tract obstruction (postrenal) rather than prerenal AKI. IV fluid administration is not indicated in this patient, as it would increase urine production, thereby exacerbating the AUR and bladder distention.
questions.hint: This patient's anuria and palpable suprapubic mass along with a distended bladder (anechoic mass) on ultrasound suggest acute urinary retention (AUR). First-generation antihistamines (e.g., diphenhydramine) increase the risk of developing this condition, especially in patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia (as suggested by an enlarged, smooth, and nontender prostate on digital rectal examination).

questions.text:
A 76-year-old man presents to the emergency department with an inability to urinate for the past 6 hours. He complains of pain in the lower abdomen and says he does not have hematuria or dysuria. He has noted decreased urinary flow and increased nocturia during the past several months. His medical history is significant for hypertension treated with lisinopril and hyperlipidemia treated with atorvastatin.
On physical examination, his blood pressure is 152/96 mm Hg, and he is afebrile. He has marked tenderness to palpation in the suprapubic region without signs of a mass. A digital rectal examination reveals a diffusely enlarged prostate; the median sulcus is not readily palpable. A urinary catheter is placed, and 600 cc of urine drains immediately.
Laboratory results are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
13.5
13.5–17.5


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
6400
4500–11,000



Creatinine (mg/dL)
2.8
0.8–1.3


His last creatinine level, measured one year ago, was within the reference range.
His urine microscopy today shows <3 red cells per high-power field (reference range, 0–2), 1 to 3 white cells per high-power field (0–2), and 2 to 10 hyaline casts per low-power field (0–5).
What is the most appropriate next step in the care of this patient?

choices.text: Obtain CT of the pelvis without contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The prostate-specific antigen level is likely to be elevated in men who have acute urinary retention; therefore, its measurement is not helpful in discerning the etiology of the acute urinary retention.

B) INCORRECT:

CT of the pelvis may be indicated in an individual with a suspected mass but would not be routinely performed in all patients.

C) INCORRECT:

Urodynamic studies are appropriate to evaluate bladder contractions and urinary flow but can be part of a secondary evaluation.

D) CORRECT:

Obstructive uropathy causes symptoms ranging from insidious overflow incontinence to overt urinary retention. Acute urinary retention is one of the most common urologic emergencies and is frequently attributable to benign prostatic hyperplasia.

Common precipitants of acute urinary retention include medications with anticholinergic properties (including over-the-counter medications such as diphenhydramine), over-the-counter cold and dietary medications (a sympathomimetic agonist may cause bladder outlet obstruction due to muscle-constricting effects on the bladder neck), constipation, infrequent voiding (in patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia), prostatitis, spinal or epidural anesthesia, opioid use, and excessive fluid administration.

Key components of the examination of a patient with acute urinary retention include a lower abdominal examination for palpation of a suprapubic mass, inspection and palpation of the genitalia, and a rectal examination to evaluate for masses, impacted stool, the size and consistency of the prostate, and anal sphincter tone.

After other causes of acute urinary retention are eliminated based on a thorough history and physical examination, alpha-blockers, such as tamsulosin, are generally viewed as first-line therapy for men with significant obstructive urinary symptoms and findings of benign prostatic hyperplasia. Initiation of an alpha-blocker upon presentation increases the proportion of patients with acute urinary retention who have a successful voiding trial at urology follow-up to over 60%, thereby obviating the need for immediate surgical intervention.

Key learning point: When treating a patient with acute urinary retention, the next step after a digital rectal examination and placement of a urinary catheter is initiation of tamsulosin.

E) INCORRECT:

Finasteride may be used to reduce the risk of symptomatic progression of benign prostatic hyperplasia, but given its slow onset of action, it would not be appropriate for a patient with acute urinary retention.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of lower abdominal pain for 3 hours. The pain is sharp, constant, and does not radiate. He has not urinated for 24 hours, and he has had no bowel movements for the past 3 days. He has been taking amitriptyline for postherpetic neuralgia for 1 week. He has a history of hypertension, nephrolithiasis, benign prostatic hyperplasia, and coronary artery disease. His medications include amlodipine, metoprolol, tamsulosin, aspirin, and simvastatin. Abdominal examination shows a palpable lower midline abdominal mass that is tender to palpation. Ultrasonography of the pelvis shows an anechoic mass in the lower abdomen. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ultrasonography of the prostate is a useful method for examining BPH, which this patient has. However, this diagnostic tool does not play a role in the management of patients with AUR.

B) INCORRECT:

NSAIDs are not suitable for the management of AUR, which requires immediate treatment of the underlying cause. Treating the pain without decompressing the bladder is contraindicated, as this will only mask symptoms. In addition, the use of NSAIDs is associated with an increased risk of AUR.

C) INCORRECT:

Ultrasonography of the kidneys is indicated to evaluate for urolithiasis or hydronephrosis (as a common sequela of urinary retention). However, this patient does not have any typical features of urolithiasis (colicky pain, dysuria, and hematuria) and hydronephrosis would be a late manifestation of AUR. Ultrasonography is not part of the immediate management of AUR and this patient should receive a different management.

D) CORRECT:

Relief of the overfilled bladder via transurethral catheterization is the treatment of choice for patients with AUR. Some drugs, such as amitriptyline and first-generation antihistamines, have anticholinergic effects such as constipation, impaired detrusor muscle contraction, and impaired urinary sphincter relaxation. These effects can cause AUR, especially in patients with BPH. Precipitating drugs should be discontinued or substituted.
Image Description:

1. After placement of the sterile drape and retraction of the foreskin, the nondominant hand holds the penis taut and upright. The urethral meatus is cleansed with antiseptic, moving outwards in a circular motion.
2. Viscous lidocaine is injected into the urethra and allowed to take effect before continuing the procedure.
3. The lubricated tip of the catheter is inserted into the urethra and passed into the bladder.
4. After the entire length of the catheter has been inserted, the recommended volume of water or air is injected into the balloon port of the catheter.
5. The catheter is withdrawn slowly until resistance is met and connected to the collection bag.

E) INCORRECT:

Digital rectal examination (DRE) is important for the diagnosis of prostatic diseases and rectal growths and is a vital part of the examination in patients with AUR to investigate the cause of urine retention. The most common cause of AUR is mechanical obstruction of the bladder outlet due to BPH, which has already been diagnosed in this patient. A DRE should be performed later in the workup to rule out other conditions that can cause AUR, but this patient is in acute pain and first requires prompt therapeutic management.
questions.hint: This patient presents with painful inability to void, a palpable bladder, and an anechoic mass in the lower abdomen, all of which are consistent with acute urinary retention (AUR). This condition requires immediate relief!

questions.text:
A 72-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with severe lower abdominal discomfort and inability to urinate for the past 12 hours. He reports increasing difficulty initiating urination and a weak urinary stream for several months. He denies fever or recent urinary symptoms. Examination reveals a palpable distended bladder. Laboratory results are pending.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Order a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tamsulosin, an alpha-1 adrenergic receptor blocker, reduces smooth muscle tone in the bladder neck and prostate, alleviating symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia. However, its gradual onset makes it unsuitable for acute urinary retention, which requires immediate bladder decompression via catheterization.

B) INCORRECT:

CT imaging is used for complex or atypical presentations of lower abdominal pain or when complications are suspected. In this classic case of acute urinary retention with a palpable distended bladder and a history of voiding difficulty, immediate bladder decompression is prioritized over imaging.

C) CORRECT:

Acute urinary retention manifests with lower abdominal discomfort and a distended bladder due to urine accumulation. This patient’s history of dysuria and weak urinary stream suggests chronic benign prostatic hyperplasia leading to acute obstruction. Immediate bladder decompression with a Foley catheter relieves symptoms, reduces intravesical pressure, and prevents complications like bladder damage or renal impairment. Catheterization also allows for quantification of retained urine, guiding further management.

Key learning point: In cases of acute urinary retention, immediate management involves Foley catheterization to relieve bladder obstruction and decompress the bladder, with urine culture to check for infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Cystoscopy is an invasive procedure for visualizing the lower urinary tract, indicated for suspected intraluminal lesions or persistent obstruction after initial management. In acute urinary retention, immediate bladder decompression via catheterization is prioritized over cystoscopy, as it provides rapid symptom relief and is less invasive.

questions.text: You are seeing a 74-year-old man who is brought to the emergency department with a 3-hour history of sharp, constant lower abdominal pain that does not radiate. He has not urinated for 24 hours and has not had a bowel movement for 3 days. He started amitriptyline for postherpetic neuralgia 1 week ago. His medical history includes hypertension, nephrolithiasis, benign prostatic hyperplasia, and coronary artery disease. His medications are amlodipine, metoprolol, tamsulosin, aspirin, and simvastatin. On abdominal examination, there is a palpable, tender lower midline abdominal mass. Pelvic ultrasonography reveals an anechoic mass in the lower abdomen. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Digital rectal examination (DRE) is important for the diagnosis of prostatic diseases and rectal growths and is a vital part of the examination in patients with AUR to investigate the cause of urine retention. The most common cause of AUR is mechanical obstruction of the bladder outlet due to BPH, which has already been diagnosed in this patient. A DRE should be performed later in the workup to rule out other conditions that can cause AUR, but this patient is in acute pain and first requires prompt therapeutic management.

B) INCORRECT:

NSAIDs are not suitable for the management of AUR, which requires immediate treatment of the underlying cause. Treating the pain without decompressing the bladder is contraindicated, as this will only mask symptoms. In addition, the use of NSAIDs is associated with an increased risk of AUR.

C) INCORRECT:

Ultrasonography of the kidneys is indicated to evaluate for urolithiasis or hydronephrosis (as a common sequela of urinary retention). However, this patient does not have any typical features of urolithiasis (colicky pain, dysuria, and hematuria) and hydronephrosis would be a late manifestation of AUR. Ultrasonography is not part of the immediate management of AUR and this patient should receive a different management.

D) CORRECT:

Relief of the overfilled bladder via transurethral catheterization is the treatment of choice for patients with AUR. Some drugs, such as amitriptyline and first-generation antihistamines, have anticholinergic effects such as constipation, impaired detrusor muscle contraction, and impaired urinary sphincter relaxation. These effects can cause AUR, especially in patients with BPH. Precipitating drugs should be discontinued or substituted.

Key learning point: Acute urinary retention requires immediate bladder decompression with transurethral catheterization to relieve symptoms and prevent complications.
Image Description:

1. After placement of the sterile drape and retraction of the foreskin, the nondominant hand holds the penis taut and upright. The urethral meatus is cleansed with antiseptic, moving outwards in a circular motion.
2. Viscous lidocaine is injected into the urethra and allowed to take effect before continuing the procedure.
3. The lubricated tip of the catheter is inserted into the urethra and passed into the bladder.
4. After the entire length of the catheter has been inserted, the recommended volume of water or air is injected into the balloon port of the catheter.
5. The catheter is withdrawn slowly until resistance is met and connected to the collection bag.

E) INCORRECT:

Ultrasonography of the prostate is a useful method for examining BPH, which this patient has. However, this diagnostic tool does not play a role in the management of patients with AUR.
questions.hint: This patient presents with painful inability to void, a palpable bladder, and an anechoic mass in the lower abdomen, all of which are consistent with acute urinary retention (AUR). This condition requires immediate relief!

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with type 1 diabetes mellitus comes to your clinic with a 3-month history of progressively worsening urinary incontinence. She reports frequent involuntary dribbling of urine, even at rest, and has started wearing incontinence pads. She also describes a sensation of incomplete bladder emptying after voiding. Her only medication is insulin. On examination, there is a palpable suprapubic mass. Urodynamic studies reveal an increased postvoid residual volume. Which one of the following is the most appropriate intervention?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pelvic floor exercises can be used to treat underactive urethral sphincters (stress incontinence) and detrusor overactivity (urge incontinence). An increased postvoid residual volume would not be expected in a patient with an underactive bladder sphincter or an overactive bladder wall. Therefore, pelvic floor exercises would not be likely to alleviate this patient's urinary retention.

B) INCORRECT:

Oxybutynin, which relaxes the detrusor muscle via M3 receptor antagonism, is used to treat detrusor overactivity (urge incontinence). Patients with urge incontinence have a sudden urge to urinate and are often unable to make it to the bathroom before leaking urine. An increased postvoid residual urine volume (bladder retention) would not be expected in a patient with urge incontinence. In this patient with urinary retention due to detrusor underactivity, oxybutynin would most likely worsen their symptoms.

C) CORRECT:

Overflow incontinence is caused by urinary retention, which can be a result of dysfunction of the bladder wall (e.g., underactive detrusor) or the sphincter (e.g., overactive urinary sphincter, benign prostatic hypertrophy). In a patient with diabetes mellitus, the most likely cause of urinary retention is an underactive bladder wall due to neuropathy of autonomic afferent nerve fibers, impairing the ability to sense bladder fullness and resulting in a decreased parasympathetic outflow (voiding neurogenic lower urinary tract dysfunction). Clean intermittent catheterization is indicated in patients with overflow incontinence to relieve chronic urinary retention and prevent complications such as urinary tract infections, urolithiasis, and vesicoureteric reflux.

Key learning point: Overflow incontinence can be managed with clean intermittent catheterization.

D) INCORRECT:

A vaginal pessary would elevate the bladder neck angle and compress the urethra against the pubic symphysis. Vaginal pessaries are used in the treatment of underactive urethral sphincters (stress incontinence). This patient has diabetes, a predisposing factor for stress incontinence. Diabetes may cause neuropathy of the pudendal nerve or the postganglionic sympathetic fibers that innervate the sphincter. However, stress incontinence would cause dribbling of urine when laughing or coughing. The use of a vaginal pessary might worsen urinary retention in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Duloxetine, which is a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor, is used in the treatment of underactive urethral sphincters (stress incontinence) because increased noradrenergic and serotonergic activity in the sacral spinal cord can increase external urethral sphincter activity. This patient has diabetes, a predisposing factor for stress incontinence. Diabetes may cause neuropathy of the pudendal nerve or the postganglionic sympathetic fibers that innervate the sphincter. However, stress incontinence would cause dribbling of urine when laughing or coughing. Duloxetine therapy might worsen urinary retention in this patient.
questions.hint: In a patient with a distended bladder, involuntary dribbling of urine and increased postvoid residual volume indicate overflow incontinence.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a history of diabetes and benign prostatic hyperplasia presents with inability to urinate for the past 8 hours. He reports taking diphenhydramine for sleep and missed his tamsulosin dose yesterday. Vital signs are BP, 150/90; P, 102; T, 37.2°C (99.0°F). Physical examination shows a distended, tender suprapubic mass that is dull to percussion. The patient appears uncomfortable and repeatedly shifts position. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Order serum prostate-specific antigen and basic metabolic panel

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bedside bladder ultrasound can confirm urinary retention, but this patient's clinical findings are already diagnostic. If acute urinary retention is clinically evident, immediate catheterization takes priority over confirmatory imaging.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with classic signs of acute urinary retention: sudden onset, painful inability to void, tender distended bladder, and distress. Acute urinary retention is a urological emergency requiring immediate bladder decompression via catheterization before any diagnostic studies.

C) INCORRECT:

Intravenous fluids are not indicated in acute urinary retention and would worsen bladder distention. The priority is immediate drainage of the retained urine using catheterization.

D) INCORRECT:

While urinalysis and culture are important in the workup of urinary retention, they should not delay urgent catheterization in acute urinary retention. This patient's clinical presentation strongly suggests acute retention that requires immediate decompression.

E) INCORRECT:

Laboratory studies including prostate-specific antigen (PSA) and metabolic panel are part of the diagnostic workup for urinary retention but should be obtained after urgent catheterization. PSA levels may be falsely elevated in acute retention and should be rechecked weeks later.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with diabetes mellitus presents with a 4-hour history of inability to urinate. Vital signs show P, 102; BP, 110/70. Physical examination shows a palpable bladder and an enlarged, firm prostate. A Foley catheter is successfully placed, draining 1200 mL of clear urine. Laboratory results show creatinine 1.4 mg/dL (baseline 0.9 mg/dL) and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) 32 mg/dL. Over the next 2 hours, he produces 600 mL of urine and reports nausea with one episode of vomiting. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Discharge with catheter removal in 24 hours
Discharge home with indwelling catheter and outpatient follow-up
Obtain urgent urology consultation for cystoscopy
Remove catheter and discharge with alpha blocker therapy
Admit for monitoring and IV fluid replacement

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Catheter removal at 24 hours is too early and increases recurrence risk. The catheter should be maintained for 3–7 days before attempting removal to optimize success rates and prevent recurrence.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient has elevated creatinine, suggesting obstructive nephropathy, plus postobstructive diuresis with nausea and vomiting, preventing adequate oral hydration. These complications require inpatient monitoring and IV fluid management.

C) INCORRECT:

Urgent cystoscopy is not indicated in the acute setting for uncomplicated urinary retention. Urgent catheterization followed by outpatient urology referral is recommended for further evaluation and definitive management of the underlying cause.

D) INCORRECT:

Immediate catheter removal would likely result in recurrent urinary retention. Catheter removal should be delayed 3–7 days, and earlier removal increases recurrence risk, especially in patients with underlying prostatic enlargement.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient has evidence of obstructive nephropathy with elevated creatinine and BUN, plus postobstructive diuresis producing > 200 mL/hour. The presence of nausea and vomiting prevents adequate oral hydration, making IV fluid replacement necessary. Hospital admission is recommended for patients with obstructive nephropathy.

questions.text: An 82-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of severe lower abdominal pain and the inability to urinate for the past 12 hours. He recently started taking an over-the-counter medication for a cold. He has a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F),  pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 158/92 mm Hg. He is agitated and appears uncomfortable. Physical examination shows a firm, distended lower abdomen that is exquisitely tender to palpation, with dullness to percussion extending halfway to the umbilicus. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?

choices.text: Administer a single dose of furosemide
Administer tamsulosin and reassess in 4 hours

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While a bedside point-of-care ultrasound could rapidly confirm a distended bladder, ordering a formal renal ultrasound is a diagnostic step that should not delay urgent therapeutic intervention. The diagnosis of acute urinary retention is clear based on the clinical presentation. The immediate priority is relieving the obstruction and the patient's severe pain, not obtaining confirmatory imaging that will not change the initial management.

B) INCORRECT:

Furosemide is a loop diuretic that increases urine production by the kidneys. In a patient with a bladder outlet obstruction, administering a diuretic is contraindicated and harmful. It would increase the volume of urine trapped in the bladder, worsening the distension, increasing the pain, and elevating the risk of bladder rupture and further renal injury. The problem is an inability to drain urine, not an inability to produce it.

C) CORRECT:

The most appropriate initial step is immediate bladder decompression via urethral catheterization. This rapidly relieves pain, alleviates the sympathetic surge causing tachycardia and hypertension, and prevents complications like post-renal acute kidney injury, hydronephrosis, and long-term bladder atony from overdistension. Precipitating factors, such as the sympathomimetic or anticholinergic agents often found in over-the-counter cold medications, are common in older individuals with BPH. After decompression, monitoring for post-obstructive diuresis is essential.

D) INCORRECT:

Tamsulosin is an alpha-1 blocker used for the long-term management of benign prostatic hyperplasia by relaxing smooth muscle in the prostate and bladder neck. While it is an appropriate medication for the underlying condition, its onset of action is too slow to be effective in this emergent setting. Delaying definitive bladder decompression would prolong the patient's severe pain and increase the risk of renal and bladder damage.

E) INCORRECT:

Suprapubic aspiration or catheterization is a valid method for bladder decompression. However, it is considered a second-line intervention. It is typically reserved for situations where urethral catheterization is contraindicated or has failed, such as in cases of severe urethral stricture, trauma, or a large, obstructing prostate. Given that a urethral approach has not yet been attempted, this more invasive procedure is not the appropriate initial step.
questions.hint: Inability to void, suprapubic pain, and a distended bladder in a patient with a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia are typical signs of acute urinary retention, a urologic emergency that requires immediate intervention.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man with a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia presents to the emergency department with severe lower abdominal pain and the inability to urinate for the past 12 hours. He reports starting an over-the-counter cold medication two days ago. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 158/92 mm Hg. On examination, he is in visible distress. There is a palpable, tender, dull suprapubic mass. A bedside ultrasound confirms a bladder volume of 800 mL. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?

choices.text: Placement of an indwelling urethral catheter

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Furosemide is a loop diuretic that increases urine production by the kidneys. Administering a diuretic to a patient with a bladder outlet obstruction is contraindicated. It would increase the volume of urine flowing into the already distended bladder, worsening this patient's pain and hypertension and increasing the risk of bladder rupture.

B) CORRECT:

Acute urinary retention is a urologic emergency characterized by the sudden inability to void. The history of benign prostatic hyperplasia is a major risk factor, and the condition was likely precipitated by an over-the-counter cold medication containing a sympathomimetic or anticholinergic agent. The goal of initial management is immediate bladder decompression to relieve pain, reduce blood pressure and heart rate, and prevent complications such as hydronephrosis or bladder wall damage. An indwelling urethral catheter (e.g., a Foley catheter) is the standard, least invasive, and most rapid first-line intervention to drain the bladder.

C) INCORRECT:

Tamsulosin is an α-1 blocker used for the long-term management of benign prostatic hyperplasia by relaxing the smooth muscle in the prostate and bladder neck. While it is an appropriate medication for the underlying cause of this patient's urinary retention, it is not the most appropriate initial step. Oral medications take hours to days to become effective and will not provide the immediate bladder decompression required in this acute, painful emergency.

D) INCORRECT:

A suprapubic catheter is a method of bladder decompression that involves percutaneously placing a tube directly into the bladder through the abdominal wall. This is an invasive procedure that is considered a second-line option. It is reserved for situations in which urethral catheterization is unsuccessful (e.g., due to a severe urethral stricture or an impassable prostate) or contraindicated (e.g., recent urethral surgery).

E) INCORRECT:

While a urology consultation is appropriate for follow-up and management of the underlying cause, it is not the most appropriate initial step. Acute urinary retention requires immediate intervention. Delaying bladder decompression to wait for a consultant to arrive would cause unnecessary suffering and increase the risk of complications. The initial placement of a urethral catheter is a standard procedure that should be performed by the emergency department provider.
questions.hint: This patient has classic signs and symptoms of acute urinary retention.
